lesson_html:
In Python, strings are immutable sequences of characters, similar to C#'s string type. There are multiple ways to combine or format strings:

String Concatenation

You can combine strings using the '+' operator, which is similar to string concatenation in C#:

first_name = 'John' last_name = 'Doe' full_name = first_name + ' ' + last_name # 'John Doe'

F-Strings (Formatted String Literals)

F-Strings, introduced in Python 3.6, provide a concise way to embed expressions inside string literals. This is comparable to C#'s string interpolation with '$' or string.Format():

age = 30 name = 'Alice' greeting = f'My name is {name} and I am {age} years old' # 'My name is Alice and I am 30 years old' # You can also include expressions print(f'Next year I will be {age + 1} years old')

F-Strings allow complex formatting, including calling methods and using expressions directly within the string.
